body: Hi, I would like to work on this. Is there a new functionality that replaces that of `Timestamp.freq`?

I don't quite know - but perhaps you can find out?
I think the full message (printed when running the test suite) has suggestions what to do, but I don't have it in front of me right now.

I'd suggest, just run the test suite and check the full deprecation message.
There are also others that may be easy to fix, like the `np.float` deprecation.

Reading the pandas PR where `freq` was deprecated (https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/15146) I now understand better why it was done. The bad news is that there is no trivial alternative to get this `freq` thing. Since a single timstamp does not have a well defined inherent frequency in it, perhaps it would be better to work exclusively with `pd.Period` objects, where frequency is totally native.
hm, could we make a converesion internally in the `ForecastingHorizon`?

issue.body:
A very large amount of deprecation messages around `timestamp.freqstr` are raised throughout the CI/CD, especially around the `ForecastingHorizon`:

```
FutureWarning: Timestamp.freqstr is deprecated and will be removed in a future version.
```

We should address this, as the `ForecastingHorizon` is a central object, so it would be catastrophic if it breaks.

At the moment, deprecation seems to be in the future since there is no specified version number yet, but we should prepare and take care of it earlier than later.

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs

Closes #1750

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.

Prohibit the use of `pd.Timestamp` type for `cutoff` in `ForecastingHorizon`.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

None

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

This solves the problem of extracting frequency from an object that will not have this property in some future (see this comment https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/15146#issuecomment-273266806 and the whole deprecation PR for details). Although the problem is solved, the solution itself is far from being ideal. The major negative consequence is the mismatch in types between a time series index, which is normally `pd.DatetimeIndex`, and the absolute forecasting horizon of `pd.PeriodIndex` obtained given `pd.Period` cutoff. This happens when the cutoff is taken to be one of the `y.index` (`pd.DatetimeIndex`) elements, which is `pd.Timestamp`. This is not allowed, so we have to convert the cutoff to `pd.Period`. The result of `fh.to_absolute(cutoff).to_pandas()` is then a `pd.PeriodIndex`.

Ideally, this conversion should happen under the hood, without a user noticing it. But it seems impossible without major refactoring. In particular, `ForecastingHorizon` is not aware of the time series itself and its frequency. So it has to obtain the frequency somehow. In the current implementation it is only `cutoff`. An alternative to consider would be to pass frequency explicitly as an argument to `ForecastingHorizon`.

#### Any other comments?

This is very controversial and touches the very core of the library, so I hope for a very careful consideration of this PR.

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs

Partially addresses #1750. More changes are necessary, but I would prefer to break the change into smaller logically complete PRs.

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.

Following this conversation: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2694#issuecomment-1146769665, and [this enhancement proposal](https://github.com/sktime/enhancement-proposals/blob/main/steps/17_forecasting_horizon_freq/step.md#2a-earlies-possible-pass-in-constructor), I added a new optional argument `freq` to the constructor of `ForecastingHorizon`.

Frequency is inferred in `ForecastingHorizon` methods indirectly, via the forecaster's `cutoff` passed to methods. In all uses, this is equal to the `cutoff` of the forecaster, which is the last time index of `y` seen in `fit`. This currently carries the `freq` for all cases of time-like indexing, but will lose it after deprecation, since single time indices will no longer carry `freq`.

In this PR frequency is passed directly upon construction or via the setter method. Cutoff is no longer used as a source of frequency information.

The biggest consequence of this design update is necessity to pass frequency to the `ForecastingHorizon` at some point for the forecasters to preserve their behavior. The minimal code change is to assign frequency via setter method to already existing `fh` in a few of `sktime.forecasting.base._base.BaseForecaster` methods. Frequency is obtained from `y` passed to `fit`, `predict`, and other public methods of this base class.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

No

body:
@khrapovs, thanks a lot for your hard and excellent work on the `freq` issue! This is truly a very fiddly and unpleasant problem.

I have been somewhat confused, I have to admit, as you may see from some replies, and have now tried to make an effort to understand things better.

Let me first try to summarize what I've understood is at the root of the problem, so you can check my understanding:

* `pandas` is going to deprecate `Timestamp.freq`. No such deprecation will happen in `Period` or `pd.Index` children that have a `freq` attribute.
* `BaseForecaster.cutoff` and `ForecastingHorizon` rely on `Timestamp.freq`. A key location is when `cutoff` is being passed, especially in `to_absolute`, to infer the shifts.

Is this correct?

If so, I might have a solution: changing the `cutoff` to `Index`, which still carries `freq`.
In a first step, we can change the private `_cutoff`, in a second step, we can deprecate `cutoff` being an index element and change it to a length-1 index as well.

The idea is, `pd.Index` descendants will still carry `freq`, even if elements are `Timestamp`. The rest should hence still work, right?
We may like to be careful with sub-setting though, since `pd.index` loses `freq` if subsetting to something that is too short, i.e., length 1 or 2.

> Is this correct?

Yes. This is more or less what I was trying to say in my enhancement proposal and in this PR description. Sorry, if it was not very clear.

> If so, I might have a solution: changing the `cutoff` to `Index`, which still carries `freq`. In a first step, we can change the private `_cutoff`, in a second step, we can deprecate `cutoff` being an index element and change it to a length-1 index as well.

As a user I am not sure I like this proposal. In exchange of passing a simple string like "D" or "10T" as a `freq` argument in a very corner case of `pd.Timestamp` (in all other cases default `freq=None` is perfectly fine), you are offering me to be very careful not to pass `y.index[-1]` directly as `cutoff` argument, but go through an additional step of converting it to an index and making sure along the way that it still has the frequency embedded. Sorry, the second option looks quite complicated. Did I get it wrong?

Here is the proposal as part of the STEP:
https://github.com/sktime/enhancement-proposals/pull/24

> Sorry, the second option looks quite complicated. Did I get it wrong?

Maybe - I think `ForecastingHorizon` should still be extended to allow `freq` pass, so if you thought I would be against that, that is not correct. I only want to propose an alternative to what happens under the hood in `BaseForecaster`, where I felt you were making sweeping changes, and preserve current usage patterns.

That is, I would like to:
* keep current user sided syntax where the `freq` arg is not required in many cases and can also be avoided in the future, imo
* change internal/private usage so the interfaces do not proliferate arguments, I think that is best achieved with an `pd.Index` typed version of the various utilities.

> Sorry, if it was not very clear.

No, it was clear - I just didn't understand it properly first time round.

> Here is the proposal as part of the STEP: [sktime/enhancement-proposals#24](https://github.com/sktime/enhancement-proposals/pull/24)

@fkiraly May I kindly remind you your own words: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2694#issuecomment-1146769665. I have spent quite some time on this PR...
